choices.text: Act as a tumor suppressor gene

questions.text: All of the following are true for TGF-beta except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • TGF-beta (Transforming Growth Factor-beta) is pro-angiogenic, not anti-angiogenic.
  • It promotes new blood vessel formation indirectly by stimulating VEGF and fibroblast activity, especially in wound healing and chronic inflammation.

Explanation of other options:

Anti-inflammatory (Option A): TGF-beta suppresses the activation of lymphocytes and macrophages, making it a potent anti-inflammatory cytokine.

Causes fibrosis (Option B): It plays a major role in fibrogenesis, stimulating collagen production and inhibiting its breakdown, contributing to tissue scarring in chronic inflammation.

Acts as a tumor suppressor gene (Option D): TGF-beta inhibits cell proliferation and can suppress early tumor development, though in later stages of cancer, it may promote invasion and metastasis.

questions.text: The following enzyme is otherwise called TACE (TNF-α converting enzyme):
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • ADAM-17 (A Disintegrin And Metalloproteinase domain-containing protein 17), also known as TACE, is the enzyme responsible for cleaving the membrane-bound precursor of tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) to release the soluble, active form.
  • It belongs to the ADAM family of zinc-dependent metalloproteinases, with roles in cytokine release, cell signaling, and inflammation.

Explanation of other options:

Matrix metalloproteinase (MMP) (Option A): MMPs are a group of enzymes that degrade components of the extracellular matrix, mainly involved in tissue remodeling, wound healing, and metastasis, not in TNF-α cleavage.

Serine proteinase (Option B): These enzymes cleave peptide bonds using a serine residue at the active site. They are involved in coagulation, digestion, and immune responses, but not TNF-α processing.

Interstitial collagenase (Option D): A type of MMP (MMP-1) that specifically breaks down collagen types I, II, and III-it plays no role in converting TNF-α.

questions.text: The epithelioid cells and multinucleated giant cells seen in granulomatous inflammation are derived from which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Granulomatous inflammation is a form of chronic inflammation characterized by collections of activated macrophages, often accompanied by T lymphocytes and sometimes necrosis.
  • The formation of granulomas represents a cellular attempt to contain difficult-to-eradicate agents, such as persistent microbes or foreign material.
  • During this immune response, T lymphocytes (especially CD4+ Th1 cells) become strongly activated and secrete cytokines like IFN-γ, which in turn activate macrophages.
  • Activated macrophages:
    • Undergo morphological transformation and develop abundant cytoplasm, becoming epithelioid cells.
    • May fuse together to form multinucleated giant cells, a classic histological feature of granulomatous inflammation.
  • Therefore, although T cells orchestrate the response, the epithelioid cells and giant cells are derived from monocytes-macrophages, not lymphocytes or other leukocyte types.

Explanation of other options:

CD4-T lymphocytes (Option A): While CD4+ T cells (especially Th1 subtype) play a crucial regulatory role by secreting IFN-γ, which activates macrophages, they do not differentiate into granuloma-forming cells.

Basophils (Option B): These are involved in allergic reactions and release histamine; they have no role in granuloma formation.

Eosinophils (Option D): Primarily involved in parasitic infections and allergic conditions (Type I hypersensitivity); they are not a source of epithelioid or giant cells.

questions.text: The histological picture of a lesion excised from the right cervical region is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows central necrosis (pale pink, acellular area in the center), surrounded by epithelioid histiocytes, lymphocytes, and multinucleated giant cells-hallmarks of a necrotizing granuloma.
  • Caseating necrosis (cheese-like) is strongly suggestive of tuberculosis or other infectious causes (fungi, some bacteria).
  • Epithelioid cells arise from macrophages activated by interferon-γ (IFN-γ) secreted by Th1 lymphocytes.

Explanation of other options:

Neurofibroma (Option B): Benign tumor of the peripheral nerve sheath, showing spindle cells with wavy nuclei and collagen in a myxoid stroma. No necrosis or granulomas.

Schwannoma (Option C): Also a benign peripheral nerve tumor; shows Antoni A and Antoni B areas with Verocay bodies, not granulomas or necrosis.

Hodgkin lymphoma (Option D): Characterized by Reed-Sternberg cells in a background of mixed inflammatory cells. No granulomas or caseous necrosis.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents with fever for one week and tender right cervical lymphadenopathy. A biopsy of the cervical lymph node was done and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows a high-power histological view of a lymph node with extensive areas of necrosis, abundant karyorrhectic debris (nuclear dust), crescent-shaped histiocytes, and absence of neutrophils.
  • These are hallmark features of Kikuchi disease (also called Kikuchi-Fujimoto disease or histiocytic necrotizing lymphadenitis).

Kikuchi Disease:

  • Typically affects young women (commonly aged 20-35 years).
  • Usually present with low-grade fever and tender cervical lymphadenopathy. It may be mistaken for lymphoma or tuberculosis clinically.
  • Etiology: The Exact cause is unknown. Likely immune-mediated in response to viral infections (e.g., EBV, HHV6, parvovirus B19). Autoimmune associations like SLE have also been observed.
  • Histopathological Features:
    • Patchy necrosis predominantly in the paracortical region
    • Abundant karyorrhectic debris (apoptotic nuclear fragments)
    • Numerous crescent-shaped histiocytes and plasmacytoid dendritic cells
    • Absence of neutrophils, which helps distinguish it from suppurative infections
  • Clinical Course: Typically self-limiting, resolving in 1 to 4 months without specific treatment. Relapses are rare but can occur.

Explanation of other options:

Kimura disease (Option A): Shows eosinophilic infiltrates, follicular hyperplasia, and fibrosis. Seen in Asian men, not necrotizing lymphadenitis.

Tuberculosis (Option C): Features caseating granulomas, Langhans giant cells, and neutrophils. Necrosis here is caseous, not clean karyorrhexis.

Castleman's disease (Option D): Has vascular proliferation, follicular hyperplasia, and plasma cell infiltration. Necrosis and karyorrhexis are not seen.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC1849878/

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Key takeaways:

Tissue Macrophages Derived from Embryonic Yolk Sac & Fetal Liver:

questions.text: A 70-year-old male dies of an acute ischemic stroke. During the autopsy, an incidental lesion is found in the apex of the right upper lobe of the lung. Microscopy reveals abundant macrophages with indistinct cell boundaries, surrounded by a rim of lymphocytes and a central zone of necrotic debris. Of the following, which is the most likely cause of this patient's lung lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The description matches a caseating granuloma, which is typical of tuberculosis (TB).

Features of TB granuloma:

  • Central caseous necrosis (amorphous eosinophilic debris)
  • Surrounding epithelioid macrophages (macrophages with indistinct boundaries)
  • A rim of lymphocytes
  • Often surrounded by Langhans-type giant cells (multinucleated)

Explanation of other options:

Tissue foreign bodies (Option A): Cause foreign body granulomas, which lack central necrosis. Often contain multinucleated giant cells trying to engulf material, but not with a lymphocytic rim and caseation.

Sarcoidosis (Option C): Forms non-caseating granulomas. Characteristically shows "naked granulomas" - granulomas with minimal lymphocyte rim. Central necrosis is absent

Crohn's disease (Option D): Granulomas can occur in intestinal walls, but they are non-caseating. Rarely seen in lung tissue, and would not have this classic histology.
Explanation:

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with granuloma formation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • MPA is a small-vessel necrotizing vasculitis that does not form granulomas.
  • It is characterized by pauci-immune necrotizing inflammation, especially of capillaries, venules, and arterioles.
  • Histologically, it shows leukocytoclastic vasculitis, which refers to fragmentation of neutrophil nuclei within vessel walls.
  • There is an absence of granulomatous inflammation, which helps distinguish it from granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's) and Churg-Strauss syndrome.
  • It is associated with MPO-ANCA (p-ANCA).

Explanation of other options:

Rheumatoid Arthritis (Option A): Rheumatoid arthritis can form rheumatoid nodules, which show palisading histiocytes surrounding a central area of fibrinoid necrosis. This is a type of granulomatous inflammation, typically found in subcutaneous tissues at pressure points.

Wegener's Granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis) (Option B): This condition features necrotizing granulomas affecting the upper/lower respiratory tract and kidneys. It is a classic granulomatous vasculitis associated with PR3-ANCA (c-ANCA) positivity.

Syphilis (Option C): Tertiary syphilis forms gummas, which are granulomatous lesions with central necrosis surrounded by macrophages and abundant plasma cells. These reflect a chronic immune response to Treponema pallidum

questions.text: Virchow cells are seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Virchow cells, also known as lepra cells, are foamy macrophages loaded with Mycobacterium leprae
  • They are a hallmark of lepromatous leprosy, where the immune response is weak, allowing for a high bacterial load within macrophages.
  • These cells appear pale and vacuolated due to the presence of lipid-rich material and numerous bacilli, and they are often found in skin and peripheral nerve biopsies.
  • Their presence helps in distinguishing lepromatous leprosy from tuberculoid forms, which are characterized by well-formed granulomas with fewer bacilli.

Explanation of other options:

Tuberculosis (Option B): In TB, the characteristic histological feature is the presence of caseating granulomas composed of epithelioid macrophages and Langhans giant cells, not Virchow cells.

Scleroderma (Option C): It is a connective tissue disorder marked by fibrosis and vascular abnormalities; foamy macrophages like Virchow cells are not seen.

Rhinoscleroma (Option D): This chronic granulomatous condition involves the upper respiratory tract and shows Mikulicz cells-large foamy macrophages containing Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, not Virchow cells.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4262048/

questions.text:
The findings shown below can be seen in which of the following conditions?
1. Q fever
2. Malaria
3. Allopurinol
4. Infectious mononucleosis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a "fibrin-ring granuloma", also known as a "doughnut granuloma", which features:

  • A central lipid vacuole
  • Surrounded by a ring of fibrin
  • Infiltrated by inflammatory cells, especially macrophages.

Fibrin-ring granulomas are a distinct form of granulomatous inflammation. They were first described in Q fever and are now known to occur in several conditions:

  • Q Fever (1): The classical association. Caused by Coxiella burnetii, especially in the liver.
  • Allopurinol hypersensitivity (3): Drug-induced reaction known to cause this granuloma pattern.
  • Infectious Mononucleosis (4): Caused by EBV, can show fibrin-ring granulomas in the liver or bone marrow.

Malaria (2): The Liver in malaria shows microgranulomas composed of Kupffer cells with pigment-laden cytoplasm. These are not fibrin-ring type and are considered nonspecific.

Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1473440/

choices.text: Predominant collagen in adult skin is type I, whereas in early granulation tissue, it is type III and I
Permanent wound contraction requires the action of myofibroblasts
Fetal cutaneous wounds heal with scar formation

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about healing?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fetal cutaneous wounds, especially in early gestation, heal by regeneration rather than repair, meaning they heal without scar formation.

This unique scarless healing is due to:

  • Reduced inflammation
  • High levels of hyaluronic acid
  • Differences in cytokine expression, such as higher TGF-β3 and lower TGF-β1 and TGF-β2
  • Presence of regenerative stem cells

This phenomenon is being studied to inform adult regenerative therapies.

Explanation of other options:

Epidermal appendages do not regenerate (Option A): Epidermal appendages include hair follicles, sebaceous glands, sweat glands, etc. After deep dermal injuries, especially full-thickness wounds, these structures are typically destroyed and do not regenerate. The regenerated epithelium lacks these appendages, contributing to functional and cosmetic deficits in healed skin.

Predominant collagen in adult skin is type I, whereas in early granulation tissue, it is type III and I (Option B): In early wound healing, Type III collagen is produced first in granulation tissue. As healing progresses, this is replaced by Type I collagen, which is stronger and more organized. Adult skin is predominantly made of Type I collagen, which gives tensile strength.

Permanent wound contraction requires the action of myofibroblasts (Option C): Myofibroblasts are specialized cells that express α-smooth muscle actin (α-SMA). They play a key role in wound contraction, helping reduce wound size by pulling the edges together. Their action is crucial for permanent contraction in wound healing, especially in large or deep wounds.

questions.text: Oval cells are seen in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Oval cells are a population of hepatic progenitor cells found in the liver.
  • These cells become activated in situations where hepatocyte proliferation is impaired, such as during chronic liver injury or inflammation.
  • The name "oval cells" comes from the oval shape of their nuclei, observed in rodent models.
  • They are located in specialized microanatomic regions called the canals of Hering, which form a connection between the bile canaliculi and the bile ducts.
  • These cells can differentiate into both hepatocytes and biliary epithelial cells, thus aiding liver regeneration when mature hepatocytes alone are insufficient.
  • However, regeneration using progenitor cells does not guarantee full restoration of normal architecture. If the structural framework of the liver is destroyed (as in a liver abscess), scarring occurs despite the regenerative attempt.

Explanation of other options:

Ovary (Option A): The ovary contains germ cells, granulosa cells, and theca cells, but oval cells are not found here. Although the ovary has progenitor-like cells for follicular development, these are not referred to as oval cells and have different embryological origins and regenerative behavior.

Lung (Option C): The lung contains type II pneumocytes, bronchiolar basal cells, and club cells (Clara cells) involved in repair and regeneration after injury. However, it does not contain oval cells. Regeneration here is mediated by different pulmonary stem/progenitor cells, especially in alveoli and bronchioles.

Heart (Option D): The adult heart has limited regenerative capacity, mainly relying on cardiomyocyte hypertrophy and possibly a small pool of resident cardiac progenitor cells. The heart does not have oval cells, and regeneration is minimal after injury, with most healing occurring via fibrosis/scar formation.

questions.text: In healing by first intention, macrophages predominantly appear on which day?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Healing by first intention (primary union) refers to the healing process of a clean, uninfected surgical wound with closely approximated edges and minimal tissue loss.

  • Day 1 (within 24 hours): Neutrophils appear at the incision margins and begin clearing debris via proteolytic enzymes. Basal epithelial cells also begin to proliferate.
  • Days 2-3: Neutrophils are replaced by macrophages, which are essential for debris clearance, angiogenesis, and stimulating fibroblast activity. This transition marks the onset of granulation tissue formation.
  • Day 5: Granulation tissue fills the incision space. Neovascularization peaks.
  • Week 2: Fibroblast proliferation and collagen accumulation continue. Edema and vascularity decrease.
  • By 1 Month: The scar becomes cellular connective tissue, largely devoid of inflammation, covered by a restored epidermis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a permanent cell type?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Smooth muscle cells are not permanent.
  • They are classified as stable (quiescent) cells, meaning they are normally in the G0 phase but can re-enter the cell cycle and proliferate in response to stimuli such as injury, vascular remodeling, or uterine enlargement during pregnancy.

Tissues of the body are broadly classified based on their proliferative capacity into three categories: Labile, Stable, and Permanent.

1. Permanent Cells

  • These are cells that are terminally differentiated, non-dividing, and incapable of regeneration after birth. If damaged, they are replaced by scar tissue.
  • Examples:
    • Neurons of the central nervous system (Option B ruled out)
    • Cardiac muscle cells (Option C ruled out)
    • Skeletal muscle cells - although classified as permanent, they have some regenerative capacity via satellite cells(stem-like cells under basal lamina) (Option D ruled out)

2. Stable Cells (aka Quiescent cells)

  • These cells are usually in G0 phase but retain the capacity to divide if stimulated by injury or cell loss.
  • Examples:
  • Smooth muscle cells → Can divide in response to injury (e.g. vascular injury repair)
    • Hepatocytes (liver cells)
    • Proximal renal tubular cells
    • Endothelial cells
    • Fibroblasts

3. Labile Cells

  • These cells continuously divide throughout life and are found in tissues that undergo constant renewal.
  • Examples:
    • Skin epidermis (keratinocytes)
    • Gastrointestinal epithelium
    • Hematopoietic stem cells in bone marrow
    • Basal cells of the oral and vaginal mucosa
    • Respiratory tract epithelium

choices.text: Involved in the development of fibrosis in the lung, liver, and kidneys that follows chronic inflammation
Stimulates fibroblast migration and proliferation, increases synthesis of collagen and fibronectin
Increased degradation of ECM due to inhibition of metalloproteinases
Anti-inflammatory cytokines limit and terminate inflammatory responses

questions.text: All of the following are true about TGF-beta except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

TGF-β (Transforming Growth Factor-beta) decreases ECM degradation by inhibiting matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) and increasing the production of tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases (TIMPs).

  • TGF-β is the most important cytokine in stimulating the synthesis and deposition of connective tissue proteins.
  • It is produced by multiple cell types in granulation tissue, especially alternatively activated macrophages.
  • It:
    • Stimulates: fibroblast migration & proliferation.
    • Promotes: synthesis of collagen, fibronectin, and other ECM components. (Option B ruled out)
    • Inhibits: MMPs → reduces ECM degradation, favoring fibrosis.
  • Pathological roles:
    • Major driver of fibrosis in (Option A ruled out)-
    • Liver (e.g., cirrhosis),
    • Lung (e.g., idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, pneumoconiosis),
    • Kidney (end-stage renal disease),
    • Pericardium (constrictive pericarditis),
    • Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma).
  • Anti-inflammatory effects (Option D ruled out):
    • Inhibits T-cell proliferation and the activity of other leukocytes.
    • Limits and terminates the immune response.

choices.text: Associated with the formation of multiple granulomas

questions.text: Chronic granulomatous disease is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is a rare congenital (not acquired) immunodeficiency caused by a defect in the NADPH oxidase complex in phagocytes.
  • This defect impairs the respiratory burst, preventing the generation of reactive oxygen species needed to kill certain catalase-positive bacteria and fungi.
  • As a result, the immune system forms multiple granulomas in an attempt to contain infections that cannot be effectively cleared.
  • Thus, CGD is characterized by recurrent infections and granuloma formation, which is why option C is correct.

Explanation of other options:

A benign neoplastic process (Option A): Incorrect. CGD is not a neoplastic condition; it's an inherited immunodeficiency disorder.

A parasitic disease (Option B): Incorrect. It is not caused by parasites; it is a genetic defect affecting neutrophil function.

Acquired leukocyte function defect (Option D): Incorrect. CGD is a congenital (inherited) defect, not an acquired one.

questions.text: An elderly man gets a burn injury to his hands. Over a few weeks, the burned skin heals without the need for skin grafting. The most critical factor responsible for the rapid healing in this case is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The skin is composed of the epidermis and dermis. The epidermis, which forms the outer layer, is regularly renewed by proliferating basal cells. The dermis houses skin adnexal structures (e.g., hair follicles, sweat glands, and sebaceous glands).
  • In partial-thickness burns, although the superficial epidermis is damaged, the deeper epithelial components within the dermis (remnant appendages) are often preserved.
  • These epithelial cells in remnant skin appendages serve as a source of regeneration, enabling rapid re-epithelialization and wound healing without the need for grafting.

Explanation of other options:

Underlying connective tissues (Option A): While important for structural support and remodeling, they do not contribute directly to re-epithelialization.

Granulation tissue (Option B): Granulation tissue helps in wound repair and angiogenesis, but does not regenerate epidermis.

Minimal edema and erythema (Option C): These are signs of limited inflammation, not direct contributors to epithelial regeneration.

questions.text: The tensile strength of the wound after a laparoscopic cholecystectomy in a 30-year-old woman depends most critically on:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • After initial collagen deposition during wound healing, the tensile strength of the wound gradually increases over weeks to months.
  • This increase is not primarily due to more collagen being made, but due to post-synthetic structural modifications:
    • Cross-linking of tropocollagen molecules
    • Increased fiber size
    • Improved fiber alignment
  • These changes strengthen the collagen network and provide mechanical stability to the healing tissue.
  • Tropocollagen, the basic structural unit of collagen fibers, must undergo extensive cross-linking to form stable, strong collagen fibrils, making option D the most accurate.

Explanation of other options:

Granulation tissue (Option A): It is essential in early wound healing for angiogenesis and fibroblast infiltration, but does not directly confer tensile strength.

Replacement of type III collagen (Option B): Type III collagen is initially deposited and later replaced by type I collagen, which is stronger. However, cross-linking is what directly increases strength, not just the replacement.

Macrophage activity (Option C): Macrophages are critical in orchestrating healing via cytokines and growth factors, but they do not directly influence tensile strength.

questions.text: Which of the following is essential for wound healing?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Vitamin C (Ascorbic acid) is critical for collagen synthesis, a major component of the extracellular matrix during wound healing.
  • It functions as a cofactor for prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase, enzymes required for hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues in collagen, which is essential for the cross-linking and stabilization of the collagen triple helix.
  • In vitamin C deficiency (scurvy):
    • Collagen is unstable and inadequately cross-linked.
    • This leads to poor wound healing, increased bleeding, and fragile capillaries.

Explanation of other options:

Balanced diet (Option A): While a balanced diet supports overall health and healing, it is not specific or essential in the way that vitamin C is for collagen synthesis.

Carbohydrates (Option B): They provide energy, which supports cell proliferation and metabolism, but are not specifically required for the wound healing mechanisms.

Vitamin D (Option C): Important for calcium homeostasis and bone healing, and modulates immune response, but not essential for soft tissue wound healing like vitamin C.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with tissue repair?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Alternatively, activated macrophages (M2 type) are involved in:

  • Tissue repair and fibrosis
  • Secretion of growth factors like TGF-β and IL-10
  • Anti-inflammatory actions and wound healing

In contrast, classically activated macrophages (M1 type) are:

  • Induced by IFN-γ and microbial products
  • Involved in pro-inflammatory responses
  • Produce reactive oxygen species (ROS), nitric oxide, and inflammatory cytokines (IL-1, TNF)

Thus, repair is predominantly mediated by the M2 subtype of macrophages.

choices.text: 3 phases in sequence are: Inflammation, proliferation, and maturation
In healing by second intention, initially first matrix containing fibrin, plasma fibrin, plasma fibronectin, and type III collagen is formed
70-80% tensile strength of unwounded skin is obtained in 3 months
After 2 months of wound healing, the increase in tensile strength is due to excess collagen synthesis

questions.text: Find the false statement about wound healing
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In wound healing, collagen synthesis is most active during the first few weeks, and by around 2 months, it begins to plateau.
  • After 2 months, further gains in tensile strength occur not due to excess synthesis, but due to remodeling and maturation of the collagen fibers.
  • This includes cross-linking of tropocollagen, increased fiber size, and alignment along stress lines—all of which enhance tensile strength without increasing collagen quantity.

Explanation of other options:

The three phases in sequence are: Inflammation, proliferation, and maturation (Option A): Wound healing proceeds in three overlapping but distinct phases:

  1. Inflammation: Hemostasis and early cellular recruitment (e.g., neutrophils, macrophages).
  2. Proliferation: Includes granulation tissue formation, angiogenesis, fibroblast proliferation, and re-epithelialization.
  3. Maturation (Remodeling): ECM is remodeled, fibroblasts reduce in number, and collagen is replaced and reorganized.

In healing by second intention, the initial matrix contains fibrin, plasma fibronectin, and type III collagen (Option B):

  • In second intention healing, which occurs when tissue loss is extensive (e.g., large wounds), healing is slower and involves more granulation tissue and scarring.
  • The initial ECM is rich in fibrin, plasma fibronectin, and type III collagen, which is later replaced by type I collagen in the remodeling phase.

70-80% of the tensile strength of unwounded skin is regained in 3 months (Option C):

  • By the end of the third month, wound tensile strength typically reaches 70-80% of normal skin strength.
  • However, it rarely regains 100%, even over time.
  • This recovery is due to both new collagen deposition and structural modification (e.g., cross-linking and fiber orientation).

questions.text: Factors that are important in the pathogenesis of this process include all of the following molecules except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histologic image shows granulation tissue, formed during tissue repair, characterized by:

  • Numerous new capillaries (angiogenesis)
  • Proliferating fibroblasts
  • Loose extracellular matrix
  • Mixed inflammatory infiltrate

Endothelin is not significantly involved in the process of angiogenesis or granulation tissue formation.

  • Instead, it is a potent vasoconstrictor peptide secreted by endothelial cells that acts mainly to regulate vascular tone and blood pressure.
  • It has no major role in endothelial cell proliferation, migration, or vessel formation, which are essential components of granulation tissue.

questions.text: Which is the collagen type present in the issue shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This histological image displays granulation tissue, identifiable by:

  • Proliferation of new capillaries (angiogenesis),
  • Infiltration of inflammatory cells (mainly macrophages and lymphocytes),
  • A loose, edematous extracellular matrix.

Granulation tissue is a hallmark of early wound healing and tissue repair.

It is characterized by the presence of type III collagen, which is:

  • Produced by fibroblasts,
  • More pliable and less tensile than type I,
  • Later replaced by type I collagen during the maturation/remodeling phase of healing.

Thus, collagen type III is the predominant collagen in this phase.

Explanation of other options:

Collagen I (Option A): Main component of mature scars, skin, bone, and tendons. It replaces type III collagen as granulation tissue matures.

Collagen IV (Option C): Found in basement membranes, not in granulation tissue. It provides structural support to epithelial and endothelial layers.

questions.text: During angiogenesis recruitment of pericytes and periendothelial cells is due to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

During angiogenesis, after new blood vessels are formed, stabilization of these vessels is essential to ensure their functionality and longevity.

This stabilization occurs through:

  • Recruitment of pericytes (which wrap around endothelial cells),
  • Periendothelial cell attachment and support.

The key mediators involved in this stabilization phase are:

  • Angiopoietins 1 and 2 (Ang1 & Ang2):
    Help in vessel maturation and interaction with the extracellular matrix.
  • PDGF (Platelet-Derived Growth Factor):
    Attracts pericytes and smooth muscle cells to the newly formed vessels.
  • TGF-β (Transforming Growth Factor-beta):
    Promotes extracellular matrix production and further vessel wall stabilization.

Explanation of Other Options:

VEGF & PDGF (Option A): VEGF is involved mainly in the initiation of angiogenesis (endothelial cell proliferation and migration), not in the recruitment of stabilizing cells.

TGF, VEGF & PDGF (Option C): Though TGF and PDGF are involved in stabilization, VEGF is not primarily responsible for pericyte recruitment, making this option less accurate.

VEGF, IL-2, IL-6 (Option D): IL-2 and IL-6 are cytokines involved in inflammatory and immune responses, not specifically in angiogenesis or vessel stabilization.

choices.text: Vascular response - Coagulation - Inflammatory response - granulation tissue - Remodeling
Granulation tissue - Remodeling - Vascular response - Coagulation - inflammatory response
Coagulation - inflammatory response - Vascular response - granulation tissue - Remodeling
Inflammatory response - granulation tissue - vascular response - Coagulation - Remodeling

questions.text: The sequential phases of the healing process:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Wound healing is a tightly regulated and sequential process involving multiple overlapping phases:

  1. Vascular Response
    • Triggered immediately after injury.
    • Includes vasoconstriction, increased vascular permeability, edema, and platelet activation.
  2. Coagulation Phase
    • Clot formation begins to stop bleeding.
    • Provisional matrix forms with fibrin and fibronectin.
    • Platelets release growth factors and cytokines to attract inflammatory cells.
  3. Inflammatory Response & Granulation Tissue Formation
    • Neutrophils and later macrophages clear debris.
    • Cytokines and growth factors stimulate angiogenesis and fibroblast recruitment.
    • Leads to granulation tissue formation.
  4. Remodeling/Fibrosis
    • Involves maturation of new capillaries (some resorb), fibroblast activity, collagen deposition (type I and III), and ECM remodeling.

choices.text: Neutrophils appear at wound margins on day 3
The epidermis recovers its maximum thickness by day 7

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding primary intentional healing?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In healing by primary intention (clean, uninfected wound with apposed edges):

  • Day 5 is the peak of neovascularization. Abundant granulation tissue forms, and new capillaries are most prominent at this stage.
  • Granulation tissue fills the incision space and brings in nutrients, oxygen, and inflammatory cells needed for repair.

choices.text: Intestinal stem cells that reside in the crypts of Lieberkuhn
The interfollicular basal keratinocyte of the skin is a source of multipotent stem cells
Bone marrow contains hematopoietic, mesenchymal, and endothelial stem cells, providing a multifaceted regenerative capacity
Fat is a rich source of multipotential mesenchymal cells

questions.text: Which is not true about stem cells?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Interfollicular basal keratinocytes in the skin are unipotent progenitor cells-they can only differentiate into keratinocytes.
  • Unlike true multipotent stem cells, they lack the ability for self-renewal and multi-lineage differentiation.
  • The true multipotent stem cells of the skin are located in the bulge region of hair follicles, not in the interfollicular epidermis.

Examples of Adult (Somatic) Stem Cells

Explanation of other options:

Intestinal stem cells reside in the crypts of Lieberkühn (Option A): True. These stem cells continuously replenish the intestinal epithelium and can differentiate into multiple intestinal cell types.

Bone marrow contains hematopoietic, mesenchymal, and endothelial stem cells, providing a multifaceted regenerative capacity (Option C): True. Bone marrow is a major source of different types of stem cells that contribute to blood formation, bone and cartilage repair, and vascular regeneration.

Fat is a rich source of multipotent mesenchymal stem cells (Option D): True. Adipose-derived stem cells are widely used in regenerative medicine due to their ability to differentiate into adipocytes, osteoblasts, chondrocytes, and more.

questions.text: Which is not a negative acute-phase reactant?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Haptoglobin is a positive acute-phase protein.
  • It increases in response to inflammation and helps bind free hemoglobin released from red cells, thereby reducing oxidative damage.

questions.text: Identify the pattern on protein electrophoresis.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The pattern shows β-γ bridging (i.e., the β and γ regions appear fused).

This is a classic finding in liver cirrhosis, due to:

  • Decreased albumin synthesis
  • Polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia from chronic immune stimulation
  • Migration of IgA into the β region

Explanation of other options:

Hypoalbuminemia (Option A): Would show a low albumin peak but no specific changes in β or γ regions. It is nonspecific and not associated with β-γ bridging.

Nephrotic Syndrome (Option B): Characteristic findings include markedly decreased albumin, increased α2 macroglobulin, and decreased γ globulins (due to loss in urine). β-γ bridging is not seen; instead, the α2 region is tall.

Acute Inflammation (Option D): Pattern includes decreased albumin and increased α1 and α2 globulins. The γ region is usually not prominent. No β-γ bridging present

questions.text: A patient's serum protein electrophoresis shows decreased albumin and a broad-based increase in gamma globulins. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Albumin is a negative acute-phase reactant, so its levels decrease during inflammation.
  • In chronic inflammation, there is polyclonal gammopathy (↑ multiple immunoglobulin types), seen as a broad-based increase in the γ region on protein electrophoresis.
  • This combination - ↓ albumin + ↑ polyclonal gamma globulins - is characteristic of chronic inflammatory states such as tuberculosis, rheumatoid arthritis, or autoimmune disorders.

Explanation of other options:

Acute inflammation (Option A): Also shows ↓ albumin, but usually with ↑ α1 and α2 globulins, not gamma globulins. The gamma region remains mostly unchanged or mildly raised.

Inherited defect in albumin (Option B): Would cause isolated low albumin without associated γ globulin elevation. It's rare and not associated with an inflammatory pattern.

Repair (Option D): This is a physiologic phase, not typically associated with a distinct electrophoresis pattern. Does not cause prominent polyclonal gammopathy.

questions.text: What is the diagnostic test of choice for Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The DHR test using flow cytometry is the gold standard for diagnosing Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD).
  • In CGD, NADPH oxidase is defective → Phagocytes can't produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) to kill microbes.
  • DHR 123 dye is taken up by neutrophils and oxidized to fluorescent rhodamine 123 in normal individuals.
  • In CGD, no or reduced fluorescence is seen → easily quantified via flow cytometry.
  • Also useful in:
    • Identifying X-linked carriers
    • Distinguishing between gp91 and p47 deficiencies

Explanation of other options:

ELISA (Option B): ELISA detects specific antigens or antibodies in serum. It is not suitable for assessing neutrophil oxidative burst or NADPH oxidase activity, which is essential in diagnosing CGD.

NBT test (Nitroblue Tetrazolium) (Option C): A qualitative test where functional neutrophils reduce NBT to a blue formazan dye. Though used earlier, it is now largely replaced by DHR flow cytometry due to lower sensitivity and subjectivity.

IHC (Immunohistochemistry) (Option D): Used to detect protein expression in tissue sections using labeled antibodies. It is not a functional test and therefore cannot assess neutrophil oxidative capacity or diagnose CGD.
